sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• daily doses above 50 mg should not be administered without CYP2D6 genotyping
  • Chorea - Huntington's disease: initial, 12.5 mg ORALLY once daily in the morning; after 1 week, increase to 12.5 mg ORALLY twice daily; if necessary, titrate by 12.5 mg at weekly intervals to a dose of 37.5 mg to 50 mg/day ORALLY in divided doses 3 times a day; MAX single dose, 25 mg; MAX daily dose, 100 mg; genotype patients for CYP2D6 if requiring greater than 50 mg/day
  • Chorea - Huntington's disease: CYP2D6 extensive and intermediate metabolizers, at doses greater than 50 mg/day, titrate at weekly intervals by 12.5 mg and give in divided doses 3 times a day; MAX single dose, 37.5 mg; MAX daily dose, 100 mg
  • Chorea - Huntington's disease: CYP2D6 poor metabolizers, titrate doses at weekly intervals by 12.5 mg; MAX single dose, 25 mg; MAX daily dose, 50 mg
  • Chorea - Huntington's disease: treatment interruption of great than 5 days, re-titrate dose; interruption for less than 5 days, resume tetrabenazine at the previous maintenance dose

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: concomitant use with a strong CYP2D6 inhibitor; maximum recommended single dose is 25 mg and the maximum recommended daily dose is 50 mg

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Chorea - Huntington's disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Gilles de la Tourette's syndrome
  • Tardive dyskinesia

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Tetrabenazine can increase the risk of depression and suicidal thoughts and behavior (suicidality). This risk must be balanced with the clinical need. Monitor patients closely for clinical worsening, suicidality, or unusual changes in behavior. Families and caregivers should be advised of the need for close observation and communication with the prescriber. Particular caution should be exercised in treating patients with a history of depression or prior suicide attempts or ideation. Tetrabenazine is contraindicated in patients who are actively suicidal, and in patients with untreated or inadequately treated depression.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• actively suicidal
  • concomitant use of an MAOI
  • concomitant use of reserpine
  • depression, untreated or inadequately-treated
  • hepatic function, impaired
  • use of tetrabenazine within 20 days of reserpine discontinuation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• depression, history; increased risk of suicidal behavior
  • diseases, treatments, or conditions that can cause depression or increased suicidality
  • suicidal ideation, history; increased risk of suicidal behavior
  • suicide attempts, history; increased risk of suicidal behavior
  • bradycardia; may increase risk of torsade de pointes and/or sudden death
  • cardiac arrhythmias, history of; increased risk of QT prolongation
  • concomitant use of other drugs that are known to prolong QTc, including antipsychotic medications (eg, chlorpromazine, thioridazine, ziprasidone), antibiotics (eg, moxifloxacin), class 1A (eg, quinidine, procainamide) and class III (eg, amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmics, or any other medications known to prolong the QTc interval; should be avoided
  • concomitant use of strong CYP2D6 inhibitors (eg, fluoxetine, paroxetine, quinidine); dose adjustment recommended
  • congenital long QT syndrome; increased risk of QT prolongation
  • CYP2D6 poor metabolizers; increased drug exposure; adjust dose
  • daily dose greater than 50 mg; CYP2D6 genetic testing should be administered prior to institution
  • depression; new development or exacerbation of preexisting depression may occur; dose reduction or antidepressant therapy may be necessary
  • hypokalemia; may increase risk of torsade de pointes and/or sudden death
  • hypomagnesemia; may increase risk of torsade de pointes and/or sudden death
  • tardive dyskinesia, irreversible, may develop; discontinue if occurs
  • neuroleptic malignant syndrome, potentially fatal, has been reported; discontinue if occurs

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Dysphagia (4% to 10%), Nausea (13%)
  • Neurologic:Akathisia (8.9% to 20%), Insomnia (22%), Parkinsonism (3% to 24%), Somnolence (17% to 57%)
  • Respiratory:Upper respiratory infection (11%)
  • Other:Fatigue (22%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval
  • Psychiatric:Depression (11% to 19%)
  • Other:Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tetrabenazine is a monoamine depletor whose exact mechanism is unknown. It depletes monoamine such as dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine, and histamine from nerve terminals.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: at least 75% absorbed
  • Effect of food: none

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Protein binding: (tetrabenazine in vitro), 82% to 85%
  • Protein binding: (alpha-HTBZ in vitro), 60% to 68%
  • Protein binding: (beta-HTBZ in vitro), 59% to 63%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic; CYP2D6 primarily; rapid and extensive.
  • Active metabolites: alpha-HTBZ, beta-HTBZ, and O-dealkylated-HTBZ

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Fecal: (oral, healthy adults), 7% to 16%
  • Fecal: (intravenous), 3%
  • Renal: (oral, healthy adults), 75%, changed

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• alpha-HTBZ, healthy adults: 4 to 8 hours
  • beta-HTBZ, healthy adults: 2 to 4 hours
  • alpha-HTBZ, mild to moderate hepatic impairment: 10 hours
  • beta-HTBZ, mild to moderate hepatic impairment: 8 hours

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in chorea associated with Huntington's disease
  • test for CYP2D6 genotyping prior to initiating tetrabenazine at doses higher than 50 mg/day
  • blood pressure and heart rate, evaluate for potential orthostatic hypotension or QT prolongation
  • new or worsening depression, suicidality, or unusual changes in behavior
  • periodically reevaluate risks and benefits of continued treatment to distinguish between drug-induced adverse effects and progression of underlying disease state
  • signs and symptoms of akathisia
  • signs and symptoms of neuroleptic malignant syndrome

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
TETRABENAZINE
USES: Tetrabenazine is a benzoquinolizine derivative used in the management of movement (dyskinetic) disorders, including chorea that is associated with Huntington's disease. PHARMACOLOGY: Tetrabenazine is a monoamine depletor whose exact mechanism is unknown. TOXICOLOGY: Excessive depletion of monoamines (ie dopamine, serotonin, norepinephrine, histamine) causes toxic effects. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare; no fatalities have been reported. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Acute dystonia, oculogyric crisis, nausea and vomiting, sweating, sedation, hypotension, confusion, diarrhea, hallucinations, rubor, and tremor have been reported in a limited number of exposures. SEVERE TOXICITY: Hypotension, syncope, confusion, and hallucinations may develop. ADVERSE EVENTS: COMMON: Drowsiness. Other events can include: orthostatic hypotension, extrapyramidal symptoms, insomnia, and nausea and vomiting. Tetrabenazine therapy may increase the risk of developing depression or suicidal thoughts and/or behaviors. Patients with Huntington's disease may be at an increased risk, especially if receiving other dopamine antagonists. RARE: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome and Parkinsonism have been rarely reported with therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
TETRABENAZINE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Patients may require airway management. Closely monitor neurologic function. Treat severe hypotension with fluids and vasopressors if necessary.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Because of the potential for CNS depression (eg, drowsiness, sedation) with tetrabenazine overdose, emesis is NOT recommended. Activated charcoal may be considered in patients who are alert or in whom the airway is protected. HOSPITAL: Activated charcoal may be considered in patients who are alert or in whom the airway is protected.
  • Airway management: Monitor airway status; intubate and ventilate as needed. Drowsiness and sedation are common.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl 10-20 mL/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine as indicated.
  • Monitoring of patient: Frequent vital signs including blood pressure; mental status, pulse oximetry as indicated. Routine laboratory studies are not indicated. Monitor fluid and electrolyte status in patients with severe vomiting or diarrhea.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Due to the fairly large volume of distribution enhanced elimination is NOT likely to be beneficial.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Asymptomatic children (other than mild drowsiness) with a minor (12.5 mg or less) inadvertent ingestion may be monitored at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: All patients with deliberate self-harm ingestions should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Children with unintentional ingestions who are symptomatic should be observed in a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with a deliberate ingestions demonstrating cardiotoxicity, or persistent neurotoxicity should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Call a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
TETRABENAZINE
TOXICITY: Limited data. Based on 8 cases of overdose, 100 mg to 1 g produced acute dystonia, drowsiness, oculogyric crisis, hypotension, confusion, diarrhea, hallucinations, rubor, tremor, nausea, vomiting and sweating. Fatalities have not been reported. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULTS: Dosing is individualized, but doses should not exceed 50 mg per day in most individuals. The maximum recommended single dose is 25 mg. PEDIATRIC: The safety and efficacy of tetrabenazine have not been established in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid concomitant use of MAO inhibitors and reserpine.
  • Advise patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness and somnolence.
  • This drug may cause worsening depression, insomnia, irritability, aggressiveness, agitation, panic attacks, and extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Instruct patient to report worsening depression, suicidal ideation, or unusual changes in behavior, especially at initiation of therapy or with dose changes.
  • Patient should not drink alcohol while taking this drug.
